What is this world with all its charms,</br>Of noisy pomp and glittering show?</br>When death displays his dread alarms,</br>Its vain delights we then forego.
Be gone!  ye false, deceitful joys!</br>Mix'd with the dregs of care and strife,</br>Your fairest promises are toys,</br>Which spoil the choicest hours of life.
For here, we see, and clearly learn,</br>Thy glory fades, and drops its bloom;</br>Our great, important, last concern,</br>We read inscrib'd on ev'ry tomb.
The curious, marble, sculptur'd bust,</br>The herald's pomp, and flatt'ring stile,</br>Old Time will crumble all to dust;</br>Destroy the fabric's lofty pile.
See!  yonder tomb, his rage displays,</br>(Whose ancient date his hand has spoil'd)</br>That sleeping dust in former days,</br>Like us with joy or sorrow toil'd.
So we, that tread this mortal stage,</br>Our fleeting sands too swiftly fall;—</br>"Act well your part, from youth to age,"</br>I hear grave wisdom loudly call.
And while we trace this solemn scene,</br>The trophy'd mansions of the dead</br>Inspire, the soul with joy serene,</br>Where e'er we gaze, or slowly tread.
Here silence holds her gloomy reign,</br>Which strikes the mind with serious awe;</br>To see all worldly pow'r and gain,</br>Submit to death's impartial law.
The monarch crown'd, the rev'rend sage,</br>The gay, the fair, the young, the wise;</br>The soldier, here suspends his rage,</br>And by the humble shepherd lies.
Death breaks the bonds of mortals pow'r,</br>Throws all their vain distinctions down;</br>Virtue, is here the richest dow'r,</br>Rewards the beggar with a crown.
But time, and death, must fall and die,</br>And cease to triumph o'er this clay:</br>Their ruin'd heaps, where e'er they lie</br>Shall smile beneath eternal day.</br>
